p.strong: Simulations on both NEURON and GENESIS

section.p: neuroConstruct holds a simulator independent representation of the cell morphology and channel mechanisms. This internal model can translated into NEURON or GENESIS code and the simulation run in either environment. This shot shows a simple Hodgkin Huxley model neuron producing the same results in either simulator. Values for the Na, K channel activation variables (m, h, n) can be plotted in each too. This also illustrates GENESIS running under Cygwin on Windows.

section.p: This image shows a number of cells connected using the Volume Based Connectivity mechanism.
A simplified model of a section of the cerebellar cortex was created in neuroConstruct, containing Purkinje Cells, Granule Cells and Mossy Fibers.

section.title: General screenshots
section.p: Neuronal morphologies can be imported into neuroConstruct, tested for errors (e.g. zero length segments) and, if necessary, edited. In this way too, more abstract neurons can be created.

neuroConstructs features an interface for browsing and managing previously run simulations. The important parameters of the simulation are recorded and so simulations run on different platforms, with different time steps, different stimuli, etc. can be replayed and compared.

Ion channel mechanisms can be created according to the new ChannelML specifications. This completely separates the physiologically relevant parameters of the ion channel (e.g. rate equations for activation and inactivation variables) from any specific simulator's implementation of the mechanism. The XML can then be mapped onto an NMODL file (for NEURON) or a GENESIS script file.
Various views can be generated to visualise network activity, such as here where cells are coloured according to average firing frequency.

section.title: Imported models
section.p: These well known models from computational neuroscience have been implemented in neuroConstruct
The complex dendritic morphology used in the Purkinje Cell model by the team at Antwerp Theoretical Neurobiology has been imported into neuroConstruct direct from the GENESIS *.p file.
Pyramidal Cell from Mainen et al A model of spike initiation in neocortical pyramidal neurons.

This model of a section of the dentate gyrus from Santhakumar, Aradi and Soltesz illustrates some of the conditions which can lead to epileptiform activity. The cells from this model have been recreated in neuroConstruct, allowing various 3D network configurations to be tested.
